intro: Aidelus micranthus, commonly known as the small-flowered aidelus, is a flowering plant native to the temperate regions of the Northern Hemisphere. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes plants like carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its aromatic foliage. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring slender stems and compound leaves with a finely divided structure. Its small, white or pale yellow flowers are arranged in umbels, a common floral pattern in the Apiaceae family. Aidelus micranthus is often found in woodland edges and moist meadows, where it thrives in partial shade and well-drained soil.
